abstract: Being a great technology company is still being learned — the easy way if you own Google and the hard way if your money is in Yahoo.
snippet: Being a great technology company is still being learned — the easy way if you own Google and the hard way if your money is in Yahoo.
lead_paragraph: IT takes more than great technology to make a great technology company. Years after the millennium bubble burst, the lesson is still being learned  the easy way if you own Google and the hard way if your money is in Yahoo.

headline.main: Two Giants, but They Aren’t Twins
headline.print_headline: Two Giants, But They Aren’t Twins

abstract: Yahoo looked to new leadership in its battle against Google. It was a bad week for automakers. Home Depot downsized by a unit, and Wal-Mart introduced products and services for the unbanked.
snippet: Yahoo looked to new leadership in its battle against Google. It was a bad week for automakers. Home Depot downsized by a unit, and Wal-Mart introduced products and services for the unbanked.
lead_paragraph: YAHOO looked to new leadership in its battle against Google. It was a bad week for automakers. Home Depot downsized by a unit, and Wal-Mart introduced products and services for the unbanked.

headline.main: Detroit Would Like Higher Numbers but Not This One
headline.print_headline: Detroit Would Like Higher Numbers but Not This One

abstract: Terry Semel failed more than any other reason, of course, because he didn’t respond properly to the challenge of Google. Number two on Mr. Semel’s list of failures, however, is he didn’t respond properly to the challenge of Facebook.
snippet: Terry Semel failed more than any other reason, of course, because he didn’t respond properly to the challenge of Google. Number two on Mr. Semel’s list of failures, however, is he didn’t respond properly to the challenge of Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Terry Semel failed as Yahoo’s chief executive more than any other reason, of course, because he didn’t respond properly to the challenge of Google. Mr. Semel passed on many opportunities simply to buy Google. And he was slow to understand Google’s key business strategies—the power of search, the money from search advertising, the enormous value in creating a network that sells ads on other Web sites, and the improbable power of running a big company like a collection of dorm room startups. What’s galling, of course, is that Yahoo was a leader in offering Web search and online advertising years before Google started.

headline.main: How Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg Shames Terry Semel
